thread.title: Boiler-room explosion causes injuries at Sunny Isles Beach high-rise
thread.title_full: Boiler-room explosion causes injuries at Sunny Isles Beach high-rise

author:
Rene Rodriguez, Michael Vasquez, Nicholas Nehamas and Patricia Mazzei 
pmazzei@miamiherald.com
title: Boiler-room explosion causes injuries at Sunny Isles Beach high-rise
text:
Boiler-room explosion causes injuries at Sunny Isles Beach high-rise 
Two adults have been rushed to the hospital 
Workers had been performing boiler-room maintenance WSVN7 Order Reprint of this Story 
A penthouse boiler room exploded atop a waterfront Sunny Isles Beach condominium Friday, injuring at least four people, according to the Miami-Dade County Fire Rescue Department. 
Two of the injured were air-lifted to Aventura Hospital and Medical Center, said Nuria Serrano, a fire rescue spokeswoman. The other two were treated for less-serious injuries at the scene. 
“Some pieces of the building fell down, and that’s how people were injured,” Serrano said. It’s possible some of the people were in an outdoor pool area. 
A gaggle of fire rescue trucks pulled up around noon to the Chateau Beach Residences at 17475 Collins Ave. The building had two gaping holes outside the top-floor boiler room, along the north side of the building, and there appeared to be another one at a service elevator. 
Chateau Beach Residences is a 33-story, ultra-luxury condo tower where unit prices average $3 million. It was completed about two months ago. 
Argentine-born developer Manuel Grosskopf, reached on his cell phone, said that three TECO Energy workers had been performing maintenance in the roof-top boiler room when the explosion occurred. 
“We don’t really know what happened,” Grosskopf said. 
This story will be updated as more information becomes available. 
Miami Herald staff writer Andres Viglucci contributed to this report, as did photographer Marsha Halper. Related content
